quiz.title: Economics: Macro vs. Micro, Markets, and Excess Demand

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of Macroeconomics?
questions.explanation: Monopoly is a microeconomic topic—it deals with individual market structures. Macroeconomics studies economy-wide aggregates.

questions.question: Excess demand occurs when:
questions.explanation: Excess demand means quantity demanded is greater than quantity supplied at the current price (a shortage).

questions.question: A perfectly competitive market has:
questions.explanation: Perfect competition is characterized by many buyers and many sellers, so no single participant can influence the market price.

questions.question: Microeconomics doesn’t deal with:
options: The study of individual economic units
questions.explanation: General equilibrium analysis studies how all markets in an economy interact and reach simultaneous equilibrium. Though sometimes considered part of microeconomic theory, it is broader and often treated separately; but given options, the others are clearly micro topics while general equilibrium is a more advanced integration of micro and macro ideas. Standard intro courses often exclude it from basic microeconomics.

questions.question: If a positively sloped linear supply curve passes through the origin, the elasticity of supply is
questions.explanation: A straight-line supply curve passing through the origin has unitary elasticity (Es = 1) at all points.

questions.question: Average cost is the sum of AVC and
questions.explanation: Average Cost (AC) = Average Variable Cost (AVC) + Average Fixed Cost (AFC).

questions.question: The horizontal supply curve parallel to quantity axis represents
questions.explanation: A horizontal supply curve means producers are willing to supply any quantity at a constant price—perfectly elastic supply.

questions.question: When output is zero, variable cost is ---
questions.explanation: Variable costs vary with output. At zero output, variable cost is zero.

questions.question: Change in quantity supplied of a product can result from
options: Change in price of related products
questions.explanation: A change in quantity supplied refers to movement along the supply curve due to a change in the product's own price.

questions.question: At prices above the equilibrium price
options: All of the above is possible
questions.explanation: When price is above equilibrium, quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded, leading to a surplus.

questions.question: When MC cuts AC, AC is at its ---
questions.explanation: Marginal cost (MC) intersects average cost (AC) at the minimum point of AC.

questions.question: An increase in market demand, supply remaining the same results in
options: Decrease in equilibrium price and increase in equilibrium quantity
Both equilibrium price and quantity rises
questions.explanation: Increase in demand with unchanged supply leads to higher equilibrium price and higher equilibrium quantity.

questions.question: There is no distinction between firm and industry in
questions.explanation: In monopoly, there is only one firm, so the firm is the industry.

questions.question: A fall in the market demand, supply remaining the same results in
options: Increase in equilibrium price and decrease in equilibrium quantity
Both equilibrium price and quantity falls
questions.explanation: Decrease in demand with unchanged supply leads to lower equilibrium price and lower equilibrium quantity.

questions.question: When MC is greater than AC, AC
questions.explanation: If MC > AC, average cost is increasing (rising).

questions.question: There is --- relationship between price and quantity supplied
questions.explanation: According to the law of supply, price and quantity supplied have a positive (direct) relationship.
